title: Myron Pottios
text:
Myron Joseph Pottios (born January 18, 1939 in <a href="Washington%20County%2C%20Pennsylvania">Van Voorhis</a>, <a href="Pennsylvania">Pennsylvania</a>) is a former <a href="American%20football">American football</a> <a href="linebacker">linebacker</a> in the <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a> for the <a href="Washington%20Redskins">Washington Redskins</a>, <a href="Los%20Angeles%20Rams">Los Angeles Rams</a>, and the <a href="Pittsburgh%20Steelers">Pittsburgh Steelers</a>. He was elected to play in 3 <a href="Pro%20Bowl">Pro Bowl</a>s.
College.
Pottios played <a href="college%20football">college football</a> at the <a href="University%20of%20Notre%20Dame">University of Notre Dame</a> and was <a href="NFL%20Draft">drafted</a> in the second round of the <a href="1961%20NFL%20Draft">1961 NFL Draft</a> by the Pittsburgh Steelers, also in the third round of the <a href="1961%20American%20Football%20League%20Draft">1961 AFL Draft</a> by the <a href="Oakland%20Raiders">Oakland Raiders</a>. He chose to play in Pittsburgh.
NFL.
Pittsburgh Steelers.
Pottios became the starting <a href="middle%20linebacker">middle linebacker</a> of the <a href="Pittsburgh%20Steelers">Pittsburgh Steelers</a> from his rookie year, 1961, up to 1965. In his rookie year, he played in all 14 games, intercepting 2 passes and recovering 1 fumble for a defense that was 7th among 14 NFL teams in points allowed. He did not play in 1962. In 1963, he played in all 14 games, intercepting 4 passes for a defense that finished 8th among 14 NFL teams in points allowed, playing alongside rookie outside linebacker <a href="Andy%20Russell%20%28American%20football%29">Andy Russell</a>. In 1964, he played in only 7 of 14 games, intercepting 1 pass and recovering 1 fumble for a defense that finished 9th among 14 NFL teams in points allowed. In 1965, he played in only 6 games, intercepting no pass and with no fumble recovery for a defense that finished 12th among 14 NFL teams in points allowed and a team that ended the season at 2-12.
Los Angeles Rams.
In contrast, when Pottios joined the Rams from 1966 to 1970, with <a href="George%20Allen%20%28American%20football%20coach%29">George Allen</a> as head coach, they were above the .500 mark throughout the period and made the playoffs twice, in 1967 and 1969, with won-lost records of 11-1-2 and 11-3, respectively. Pottios was the starting <a href="middle%20linebacker">middle linebacker</a> from 1967 to 1970, playing between <a href="outside%20linebacker">outside linebacker</a>s <a href="Jack%20Pardee">Jack Pardee</a> and <a href="Maxie%20Baughan">Maxie Baughan</a> throughout. In 1966, Pottios played in 12 games, but was the backup middle linebacker to the 37-year-old <a href="Bill%20George%20%28American%20football%20player%29">Bill George</a> who played in all 14 games. In 1967, he played 11 of 14 games, intercepting 1 pass and recovering 1 fumble for the best defense in the league among 16 NFL teams in points allowed. That team lost to the <a href="Green%20Bay%20Packers">Green Bay Packers</a> in the divisional round, in which Pottios started at middle linebacker. In 1968, he played all 14 games, recovering 4 fumbles for a defense that finished 3rd among 16 NFL teams in points allowed. But, in 1969, he played in only 5 of 14 games, replaced by <a href="Doug%20Woodlief">Doug Woodlief</a>. That team lost to the <a href="Minnesota%20Vikings">Minnesota Vikings</a> in the divisional round with Woodlief as the starter. In 1970, his final year with the Rams, he regained his starting middle linebacker position, playing in all 14 games, with 2 interceptions and 2 fumbles recovered for a defense that finished 4th among 26 NFL teams in points allowed.
Washington Redskins.
Pottios, along with <a href="Jack%20Pardee">Jack Pardee</a>, <a href="Maxie%20Baughan">Maxie Baughan</a>, <a href="Diron%20Talbert">Diron Talbert</a>, <a href="John%20Wilbur%20%28American%20football%29">John Wilbur</a> and <a href="Jeff%20Jordan%20%28American%20football%29">Jeff Jordan</a>, followed head coach <a href="George%20Allen%20%28American%20football%20coach%29">George Allen</a> to the Redskins which also acquired a <a href="1971%20NFL%20Draft">1971</a> fifth-round pick (124th overall–traded to <a href="Green%20Bay%20Packers">Green Bay Packers</a> for <a href="Boyd%20Dowler">Boyd Dowler</a>) from the Rams for <a href="Marlin%20McKeever">Marlin McKeever</a>, first and third rounders in <a href="1971%20NFL%20Draft">1971</a> (10th and 63rd overall–<a href="Isiah%20Robertson">Isiah Robertson</a> and <a href="Dave%20Elmendorf">Dave Elmendorf</a> respectively) and third, fourth, fifth, sixth and seventh rounders in <a href="1972%20NFL%20Draft">1972</a> (73rd, 99th, 125th, 151st and 177th overall–to <a href="New%20England%20Patriots">New England Patriots</a>, traded to <a href="Philadelphia%20Eagles">Philadelphia Eagles</a> for <a href="Joe%20Carollo%20%28American%20football%29">Joe Carollo</a>, <a href="Bob%20Christiansen">Bob Christiansen</a>, <a href="Texas%20Southern%20Tigers%20football">Texas Southern</a> defensive tackle Eddie Herbert and to <a href="New%20York%20Giants">New York Giants</a> respectively) on January 28, 1971.
Playing up to 1973, his team reached the playoffs all three years, inserted between outside linebackers Pardee (1971–72) or <a href="Dave%20Robinson%20%28American%20football%29">Dave Robinson</a> (1973) and <a href="Chris%20Hanburger">Chris Hanburger</a> (1971–73). In 1971, Pottios played in all 14 games and had one interception for a defense that finished 4th of 26 teams in the NFL in points allowed. That team lost a divisional round game to the <a href="San%20Francisco%2049ers">San Francisco 49ers</a> in which Pottios started. In 1972, he played in only 7 games of 14 games, replaced by <a href="Harold%20McLinton">Harold McLinton</a>, and recovered 1 fumble for a defense that finished 3rd of 26 teams in the NFL in points allowed. However, Pottios was the starting middle linebacker in all 3 playoff games the Redskins played that year, when they won a divisional round game against the <a href="Green%20Bay%20Packers">Green Bay Packers</a> and the NFC championship game against the <a href="Dallas%20Cowboys">Dallas Cowboys</a>, in which the <a href="Roger%20Staubach">Roger Staubach</a>-led Cowboys were limited to a miserable 169 yards of total offense and 3 points. However, Washington lost <a href="Super%20Bowl%20VII">Super Bowl VII</a> to the <a href="Miami%20Dolphins">Miami Dolphins</a> 14 to 7, in which they could not handle the running attack led by <a href="Larry%20Csonka">Larry Csonka</a>. In 1973, his final year in the NFL, he played in only 6 of 14 games, but started a divisional round match against the <a href="Minnesota%20Vikings">Minnesota Vikings</a>, losing his final game.
